Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of the Bartik High-Performance Computing Cluster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a computational cluster named Bartik, supports faculty research employing high-performance computing (HPC) needs and undergraduate education within the home departments of all investigators and senior personnel, and creates opportunities for additional faculty, new or existing, to implement computational aspects into research and/or teaching endeavors in this mainly undergraduate serving institution. (The cluster is named after Jean Bartik, a pioneering woman in the field of computer science and programming and a Northwest alumnus.)

Large datasets continue to become increasingly common in many studies. Web-based commerce has allowed marketing data to grow exponentially, and breakthroughs in laboratory technology have enabled collection of vast datasets that were previously unattainable. These data can no longer be stored, manipulated, or analyzed on desktop computers, leaving HPC as a main outlet for many studies.
NWMSU interacts with the supercomputing network XSEDE, but relatively few projects require its exceptional resources. The computational cluster would support projects outlined in this proposal and allow benchmarking and piloting of code to be run on XSEDE resources. Bartik would service both the research and education needs at NWMSU undergraduate and graduate students, as well as some high school students that are frequently engaged in faculty research. Research experiences for these students are invaluable and often lead to increased success and retention rates in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) fields. This cluster would also support a new undergraduate program in Data Sciences that will begin accepting students in the Fall of 2016. Within this course of study, undergraduate students in Mathematics, Computer Science, Business, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and Biology will be trained to work with big data using coding, statistical, and visualization approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Northwest Missouri State University (NW) is a Primarily Undergraduate Institution in Maryville, MO. Teaching is our primary mission, but research productivity is stressed. In particular, undergraduate research projects are strongly encouraged, valued and funded by the NW Administration. Several NW faculty use computational approaches to research questions. Moreover, large-scale datasets are increasingly common across all disciplines, prompting NW to initiate a Data Sciences major in 2017. However, high-performance computing resources for research and teaching were not available at NW or nearby. An interdisciplinary grant team was assembled from the Departments of Natural Science, Mathematics and Statistics, Geography, Computer Science and Information Systems and Business to request cyberinfrastructure funding. NSF funds granted through the CI-MRI Program allowed NW to purchase a compute cluster. This cluster was named Bartik in honor of Jean Jennings Bartik, a pioneer of computer programming and a NW alumnus.

Bartik has allowed numerous faculty and students across multiple disciplines to advance their computational research. These research projects produced one microbial-ecology publication with NW faculty, undergraduate- and graduate-student coauthors in 2018. Bartik has enabled analyses for an additional four publications in physics, three publications in microbiology and two publications in computer science. Six poster presentations at scientific conferences have also resulted, with at least four more planned for the Spring of 2020. Lastly, Bartik has enabled assembly of the first genomes sequenced at NW. Importantly, these 18 bacterial cultures were isolated and genomes assembled and analyzed by NW undergraduate researchers.

Although the grant period has ended, Bartik currently has achieved its largest number of users, is under its heaviest usage and has initiated a new era of computational research at NW. We anticipate that faculty and students will continue to rely upon Bartik for at least three more years. During that time, we expect Bartik to support the endeavors of many new faculty and students and produce additional publications and presentations. In essence, NSF funding for Bartik will have an impact on NW that will last long after the funding period has ended.
